content.webTitle: Talking Horses: Titans of turf plot to thwart O'Brien in Irish Derby

fields.headline: Talking Horses: Titans of turf plot to thwart O'Brien in Irish Derby
fields.bodyText: If experience counts for anything, Aidan O’Brien is in terrible trouble as he seeks to win the Irish Derby for the 13th time. Admittedly, there are only three runners in today’s Classic from stables other than his own but they are trained by titans of the Irish turf, Dermot Weld, Jim Bolger and Kevin Prendergast, all of whom were doing the job by the time young Aidan was seven years old. Between them, those grandees have accumulated 146 years with a licence, during which time they have surely learned all there is to know about preparing a talented young racehorse for the big occasion. We must hope they haven’t forgotten much of it, because the participation of their horses is the only thing stopping this Derby from esembling an exercise gallop at Ballydoyle. Prendergast, a week shy of his 87th birthday, has the most obvious chance of foiling O’Brien. Four weeks ago at Epsom, his Madhmoon defied doubts about his stamina to be a close second in the Derby and now he is just a 5-2 shot to give Prendergast a first success in a race his father, Paddy, won four times. “It would be the crowning glory on all the races I’ve won, over the years,” Prendergast reflected on Friday at his Friarstown Stables, about two miles from The Curragh racecourse. It is 42 years since he successfully raided Newmarket, sending over the 20-1 shot Nebbiolo to shock the locals in the 2,000 Guineas. Only a fool could have underestimated him since that day and Madhmoon’s career suggests his powers have not waned one bit. To win today, his colt must turn around the form with O’Brien’s Anthony Van Dyck, who may have been on a faster strip of ground at Epsom after switching to the far rail in the closing stages. “He’s going to be a hard horse to beat again,” muses Prendergast, who is not inclined to complain about the way the Derby panned out. “It’s only half a length. If my horse improves a length, he wins the race! That’s if he races the same as he did at Epsom, and we’re hopeful that he will. “It was a tactical sort of race but I don’t think there were too many hard luck stories. It was pretty clean. Look, whichever one has the best luck this time will probably win.” At least there have been no bumps in the road in the intervening month. Indeed, Chris Hayes, Madhmoon’s jockey, is evidently bubbling over with hope, telling a reporter on Friday: “As crazy as it sounds, I think he’s improved.” The more phlegmatic Prendergast will not go quite that far. “He couldn’t be better. He’s only done bits of pace work and a couple of swingers. He’s very fit and in good shape. I hope we get the nod this time.” Weld’s Rakan has rather more to prove, though the two horses he beat last time both ran well at Royal Ascot recently. “I expect him to run a good race,” Weld said of the 20-1 shot. Bolger could be accused of an excess of optimism in running Guaranteed, if there was anyone brave enough to say such a thing anywhere near him. Available at 66-1, the horse scrambled home in a much lower grade last time but he is improving and his trainer has evidently held him in high esteem for some time. “We’re just hoping the step up to a mile and a half will bring out a bit more in him,” said Kevin Manning, rider of Guaranteed and son in law to Bolger. Tellingly, he added: “I loved the way Kevin’s horse went to the line at Epsom and I think whatever beats him will win.” O’Brien fields five runners but there is no doubt his preferred outcome is for Anthony Van Dyck to become a dual Derby winner and popular stallion prospect. At least this time the master trainer doesn’t have to worry about his son, Joseph, whose Latrobe won last year’s Irish Derby. O’Brien Jr lacks a runner this time but he still has much to celebrate, having saddled Iridessa to win Friday night’s Group One, the Pretty Polly. O’Brien Sr had to make do with the placed horses, Magic Wand and the one-paced Pink Dogwood.
